speaker: Niles
text: I can't believe how cold it is in here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, the climate control is on, it's perfectly comfortable.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really?  Touch your tongue to the seat belt, I dare you.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm starting to regret I even asked you to this exhibit.  I wanted to invite Regan, but after the disaster I made of our first date I just felt too ashamed to even ask.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you can't avoid her forever, she's your neighbor. Ask her again, what's the worst thing that can happen?

speaker: Frasier
text: She'd ask me to stop harassing her, which would mean I'd have to spend the next six months riding in the service elevator with Guillermo and his three-legged cat!

speaker: Niles
text: How is little Wobbles?

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see what you're doing, Niles!  If you're so cold there's a scarf in the glove compartment.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really?  I thought that's where you kept the butter and the eggs.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, now it's burning up in here!  I'm gonna take this coat off.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you insane?

speaker: Niles
text: At least wait until we've stopped...

speaker: Frasier
text: Take the wheel!

speaker: Niles
text: I'll take the wheel but... Frasier, stop. [_looks into road_] Stop!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, it's almost off.

speaker: Niles
text: No, I mean brake, brake! _Frasier crashes into the next car in a minor fender bender. The airbags deploy and squash the Crane boys._

speaker: Niles
text: Are you all right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Thank heavens your fist softened the blow of the airbag! _FADE OUT  Scene Two - Accident & Emergency Frasier and Niles are waiting to be called.  Frasier is holding a blood-stained tissue to his nose.  A man, Phil, is sitting next to them. _

speaker: Phil
text: Hurt your nose?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looks at Niles_] Yes.

speaker: Phil
text: That's what I figured.  Right when you came in, I said, "That guy hurt his nose."  So how did you, you know...

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, hello, this is Dr. Frasier Crane here.  I was just wondering, I filled out my paperwork about half an hour ago.

speaker: Receptionist
text: They'll call you.  We're seeing people in order of importance.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh really, well, I do have my own radio show.

speaker: Receptionist
text: The importance of the injury!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to receptionist_] Do you know, are there any plastic surgeons on call?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, that's not necessary.

speaker: Niles
text: Can't be too careful, could be broken.

speaker: Receptionist
text: Don't worry, the best plastic surgeons in town have their offices here.  Dr. Rab, Dr. Karnofsky and Dr. Burke.

speaker: Niles
text: Karnofsky?  Mel Karnofsky?

speaker: Receptionist
text: That's right.

speaker: Niles
text: Maris's plastic surgeon.  Would you believe that charlatan is still picking my pocket a year after my divorce?

speaker: Frasier
text: Good Lord, for what?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, for Maris's botox injections.  They use those botcholeanen toxins that you put in the forehead, it deadens the muscles and takes away the wrinkles.  I gave it to her as a gift one year for our anniversary.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes, probably your tenth.  That's toxins, isn't it?

speaker: Niles
text: Anyway, Karnofsky keeps billing me for her follow-up injections.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good Lord.

speaker: Phil
text: So you're divorced, huh?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.

speaker: Phil
text: Me too, I'm Phil. [_puts his hand out, Niles doesn't reciprocate_] Fourteen years together.  Came home one day and... oh hell, I probably shouldn't even talk about it.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Niles, seeing as how we're here, why don't you go and find this Karnofsky and straighten this whole thing out?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, I can't leave you here injured.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's all right, Niles, I'll be fine.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you sure?  I may just pay Dr. Karnofsky a visit.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, it really is outrageous what these scalpel jockeys get away with; convincing women like Maris to spend fortunes on their exterior, when frankly what they need is to take a good look at the woman inside.

speaker: Niles
text: Right.  Well, she did have one chemical pill where you could see her kidneys for a while.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughs_] Off you go.  Good luck, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you. _Niles walks off down the corridor.  Frasier looks over at Phil who is now sat down reading the newspaper.  He slowly edges to the seat next to him, making sure he is not seen over Phil's paper.  Frasier thinks he's safe until..._

speaker: Phil
text: [_lowers paper_] Not a pretty woman, my wife, but when she danced you couldn't keep your eyes off her.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, actually I'm feeling a lot better, goodbye! _Frasier gets up and runs out of the hospital.  Then the nurse comes to the front desk and calls._

speaker: Nurse
text: Frasier Crane? [_no response_] Frasier Crane, we're ready to see you.

speaker: Phil
text: That's me! _Phil gets up to go with the nurse.  FADE TO:_ **WHAT, ME WORRY?** _Scene Two - Mel Karnofsky's Office. The office is decorated well with objets d'art.  Niles is admiring the art as a man in a lab coat enters with a large, heavy box of files._

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, Dr. Karnofsky, I see you've decided to make time for me!

speaker: Clerk
text: Sorry, I'm from Records.  I was told to bring over Maris Crane's files. [_places the box on the desk_] That's this year. _The man then exits as a woman in a white lab coat enters from another door._

speaker: Mel
text: Dr. Crane?

speaker: Niles
text: [_turns around_] Yes.

speaker: Mel
text: I'm so sorry to keep you waiting.  Melinda Karnofsky. _To Niles's surprise, Mel Karnofsky is not just a woman, but a rather attractive one - with fine pale features, curly dark hair, and an ultra-fastidious air that he always thought was his exclusive province._

speaker: Niles
text: [_taken aback, shakes her hand_] Oh, yes, of course, Niles Crane.  About this billing issue...?

speaker: Mel
text: Oh my God, this box is filthy. _She takes a wet wipe from her drawer and cleans her hands, which seems to fascinate Niles._

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, the problem is I have received three invoices over the past six months.

speaker: Mel
text: Yes, I'm so sorry about that.  And I'm so sorry about all this dust.  Do you mind, I'll have to turn on my hepafilter?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you have a hepa... [_notices and gasps_] You have a Svenson!

speaker: Mel
text: Yes.  They're great, aren't they? [_turns it on_]

speaker: Niles
text: Not to mention impossible to get in this country, I've tried.

speaker: Mel
text: Well, I once did a favor for Mrs. Svenson.  Oh, it's a long story.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm all ears.

speaker: Mel
text: So was she.  Anyway, I've spoken to the accounting department about your bill and it was clearly our mistake.  Please accept our apology, we'll take care of it.

speaker: Niles
text: I appreciate that. _Niles notices a print on the wall.  It is a portrait of a woman done in the typical Cubist fashion of Picasso._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I like that print very much.

speaker: Niles
text: Everything all right?

speaker: Mel
text: I'm sorry, I just noticed a smudge on my jacket. [_points to an invisible mark_]

speaker: Niles
text: It's barely noticeable.

speaker: Mel
text: You're being kind. _Mel takes her jacket off - showing him a slender waist and an alluring pair of bare shoulders - and pops it in the bin._

speaker: Mel
text: I got that print at the last museum show.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I thought you looked familiar.  Perhaps I've seen you there.

speaker: Mel
text: Perhaps.  I go to all of the openings, I'm on the museum board.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?  Well, congratulations.  All the exhibits this year have been... _Mel opens her wardrobe to reveal several identical white lab coats hung in seamless order.  Niles notices._

speaker: Niles
text: [_passionately_] Perfection!

speaker: Mel
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: I particularly like the Picasso.  I'm a big fan of his Cubist period.

speaker: Mel
text: Oh, striking, isn't she?  Yes, I'd like to think if she came in here I could have actually helped her. [_Niles laughs_] You must think I'm terribly fussy.

speaker: Niles
text: [_passionately_] Yes.

speaker: Mel
text: Anyway, it was very nice meeting you.

speaker: Niles
text: Likewise.

speaker: Nurse
text: [_v.o._] Dr. Karnofsky, Mrs. Magreshack has a question for you in room three.

speaker: Niles
text: Helen Magreshack?

speaker: Mel
text: Oh, I really can't say.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh. [_turns away, then leans in_] She's finally having it removed?

speaker: Mel
text: Why did she wait?!

speaker: Niles
text: I don't know! _They laugh.  Mel exits as the man enters again.  This time he has several file boxes stacked on a hand truck._

speaker: Clerk
text: Found '98.

speaker: Niles
text: Actually, that's all been settled. [_picks up photo on desk_] Can you tell me, is that her husband?

speaker: Clerk
text: No, she's divorced.  That's her son.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?  Dr. Karnofsky's so young, she must have had him when she was a child.

speaker: Clerk
text: [_skeptical_] Okay.

speaker: Mel
text: Oh, was there something else?

speaker: Niles
text: Er, no. [_walks away then_] Er, no.  Well-

speaker: Mel
text: Yes?

speaker: Niles
text: Mel, er... I was wondering, I, er...

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  Er, I'm not really sure how to ask.

speaker: Mel
text: I think I know what it is.

speaker: Niles
text: A-ha.

speaker: Mel
text: And you've got no reason to be nervous.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really?

speaker: Mel
text: Yes.  Just a few quick injections and those nasty little wrinkles in your forehead will disappear.

speaker: Mel
text: Well, that is what you were going to ask, isn't it?

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughs_] Yes.

speaker: Mel
text: Well, it's a very simple procedure.  Although your forehead will be numb for a while.  I can fit you in at four-thirty.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh good, that gives me time to do something I need to do.

speaker: Mel
text: Excellent... [_exits_] _As soon as she's gone, Niles throws a barrage of slaps at his own forehead in anger at himself.  FADE TO:_ **DEAD MAN WATCHING** _Scene Four - Frasier's Apartment. Martin is sat in his chair reading the paper.  Frasier is sat watching the news, holding a cold compress to his nose.  The doorbell sounds. Daphne answers the door to Niles._

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.  I was on my way home, I thought I'd see how the patient was doing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm fine, thank you, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: You have no idea how guilty I'm feeling. [_to Daphne_] I suppose he told you it was my fist that struck in the inadvertent yet powerful blow.

speaker: Frasier
text: So how did things go with the nefarious Dr. Karnofsky?  Did you give him a piece of your mind?

speaker: Niles
text: Actually he turned out to be a she, and quite a reasonable she at that. [_sits next to Frasier_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  That's quite a turnabout.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, well...

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane, don't move.

speaker: Niles
text: Why?

speaker: Daphne
text: There's a mosquito.

speaker: Niles
text: Where?

speaker: Daphne
text: On your forehead.

speaker: Niles
text: Uh-oh! [_pats about acting on his head_] Get off, get off.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's already gone.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh dear, looks like it bit you.

speaker: Niles
text: All right... [_acting_] Ow!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, wrinkle your forehead for me, will you?

speaker: Niles
text: Why would I do that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Just do it.  Wrinkle your forehead.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm not your marionette!

speaker: Frasier
text: You got a botox injection!  You've got a forehead full of poison right now, don't you?

speaker: Niles
text: I do not!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_looking at the floor_] Well, that's strange.  The mosquito fell right out of the air, dead. [_picks it up and bins it_]

speaker: Martin
text: What's a botox injection?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's a cosmetic procedure they use to eliminate facial wrinkles.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh great, my kids are having plastic surgery.  That's a nice age to get to.

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't believe you let Maris's witch doctor work her magic on you.

speaker: Niles
text: Mel is a perfectly lovely person!  In fact, I was screwing my courage up to ask her on a date when she noticed this little flaw and I lost my nerve.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and most of the feeling in your face as well!

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane, look, your picture's on the news.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, turn it up, Dad, turn it up. _We then see a close-up of the television.  Over the newscaster's shoulder is a studio portrait of Frasier, with the caption, "Frasier Crane: 1952 - 1999."_

speaker: Anchor
text: After checking into the hospital with what appeared to be minor injuries from a fender-bender, radio psychiatrist Frasier Crane died suddenly today.  I'm sure it goes for all of us here at KYLL when I say he'll be sorely missed. [_cheerful_] But this rain won't be missed, will it, Flip?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God!

speaker: Martin
text: What the hell?

speaker: Daphne
text: That's unbelievable!

speaker: Niles
text: [_flat face, shocked voice_] Outrageous!  [_N.B. Frasier's birth year is given here as 1952 -- three years before Kelsey Grammer's actual birth date.  Thus, at this time Grammer is forty-four but Frasier is forty-seven._] _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene One - Caf e Nervosa Frasier is talking to Roz on a front table. _

speaker: Frasier
text: As it turns out, after I left the hospital some poor devil used my name to jump the line and he dropped dead of a heart attack.  I must say, it does seem a bit strange having plunged all of Seattle, albeit temporarily, into so much grief.

speaker: Roz
text: I know, I'll never forget where I was when I heard you had died.  I was out on the street.  There was this crowd watching a television through a department store window, and before I knew it, we were weeping and hugging each other.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very amusing, Roz!

speaker: Roz
text: And then it began to rain, and I had this feeling that all the angels were crying.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_irate_] Yes, all right, Roz! _Martin arrives from the back of the caf e with a copy of a newspaper. _

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Roz.  Fras, have you seen this? [_hands him the newspaper_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, as a matter of fact, I did. [_to a puzzled Roz_] It's my obituary.

speaker: Roz
text: They printed it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, they must have picked it up off the wire last night before the news ran that correction.

speaker: Martin
text: Jimmy gave it to me at McGinty's.  Boy, everybody was so nice to me, buying me beers and everything.  You know, because of the shock I went through thinking I'd lost my son.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what are you talking about?  You didn't think I was dead!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, people don't have to know that.  I could have been at home alone, wondering where you were and I get this strange uneasy feeling.  So I turn on the TV and there it is on the screen: the face of my dead son.

speaker: Frasier
text: But I was sitting right beside you!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what kinda story is that?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's the truth!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, the truth doesn't put anything on a coaster!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, there's something for your scrapbook, huh?  Your own obituary. [_begins to read it_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well... you know, frankly, it's-it's a little upsetting.

speaker: Roz
text: [_looks up_] I don't think they meant to be insulting, you are "lovably pompous."

speaker: Frasier
text: Not that.  It's just, seeing all my life in black and white, it just all looks a little incomplete.

speaker: Roz
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I was going to do so much with my life.  I was going to write a novel, run for public office, I was gonna do my own translation of Freud...

speaker: Roz
text: Well, what's stopping you?  You're not actually dead.

speaker: Frasier
text: I guess you're right. [_laughs_] I'm not dead, am I? [_laughs_] You know, maybe that's a good way of looking at this actually, more of a wake-up call.

speaker: Lady
text: Dr. Crane, I was so relieved to hear that you're all right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: Lady
text: I heard the news and I thought, "What a shame, why he is such a young man."

speaker: Frasier
text: That's so nice of you.  Thank you, thank you so much.  You know, you're right.  What am I doing frittering away my day here in this coffee house? [_stands_] You know, I've got things to do.  I've got fresh world to conquer.  I'm going to go out there and grab life by the scrub.  Look out destiny, here I come! _Frasier marches to the door and exits out onto the street.  However, a rumble of thunder followed by a downpour of rain sees Frasier hurrying back in wiping the water from his coat._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_excusing_] Well, it's really coming down out there. _FADE TO:  Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. Frasier is working on his laptop on the dinner table wearing a tatty old sweater and jogging pants as Daphne enters with the laundry. There are food baskets all around the place._

speaker: Daphne
text: What happened to your clothes?  Did you spill something on yourself?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, I'm going jogging later.

speaker: Daphne
text: No need to be sarcastic, just give me the clothes and I'll do another load.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm serious, Daphne.  I plan to go running just after I finish my obituary. [_off Daphne's glance_] It's a self- actualizing exercise.  You write your obituary the way you'd like it to appear - years from now, of course - and then it helps you to focus your goals. [_sits back_] Here they are, all my hopes and dreams.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_looks at monitor_] These are dreams, all right. [_laughs, then reads_] "Dr. Crane came late to athletics, he became a fixture in the Seattle marathon, the America's Cup yacht race, as well as the Kentucky Derby." [_laughs_] A jockey at your size!  You better start writing an obituary for the horse.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very amusing, Daphne.  I meant as a stable owner.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey Fras.  What you do?  Spill something on your clothes?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm going jogging later.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, there's no need to get sarcastic about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm serious, Dad, I'm going to have to start somewhere if I plan to run a marathon! _Martin, however, hasn't listened and notices another food basket on the console behind the sofa.  He takes a closer look._

speaker: Martin
text: Ooh, we've got a new basket?  Hickory Farms!

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, that one came this afternoon.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, we agreed that we were going to send back all the condolence baskets intact.

speaker: Martin
text: I know, I know, but, you know, if a can of pecans falls out here and there, who's going to notice?  Oh, by the way.  Guess who I ran into?  That friend of yours from next door, Regan.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  You know, she was pretty relieved to hear you weren't dead.  You know, maybe there's still something going on there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't know, Dad.  I'd like to believe that, but I'm just too much of a realist.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_reads screen_] Tell that the two million people a year who visit "Frasier Land." [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a website, it teaches children about psychiatry!

speaker: Martin
text: Hi.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, hi Dad.  I can't stay, I just realized I think I left my cell phone here last night.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yeah, I did see it somewhere.  Let me just have a look for it...

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Frasier_] Why are you wearing running clothes?

speaker: Martin
text: He won't tell us!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_picks up cell phone and hands it to Niles_] Here it is.  It was buried back here underneath all these baskets.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Daph!  Look what you did!  Rooting around in there, you poked a hole right through this... [_Martin quite obviously punches a big hole through the cellophane on purpose_] Hickory Farms basket!  We can't send it back now! [_He takes it to his chair._]

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you, Daphne.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes?

speaker: Frasier
text: Is that a bandage sticking out of your shirt?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, where?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, right there. [_points to one on the back of his neck_]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh yes, I cut myself shaving.

speaker: Frasier
text: On the back of your neck?  You went to see Karnofsky again, didn't you?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I did!  I was going to ask her out again, when I got all flustered and I caught her staring at this grotesque carbuncle.

speaker: Frasier
text: Carbuncle?  You mean that miniscule mole of yours.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, to you.  I've always been self-conscious about it. I've made many a hasty wine selection because I felt the

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, please.  Just knock this off.  Isn't it time you just asked the woman out?

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I'm just waiting until the moment's right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Like you did with Daphne?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, I am sorry.  But I'd like to see you do this while I can still pick you out of a crowd.  You know, I've got tickets for the opera tonight.  Why don't you ask her to join you?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I don't know. [_sits down_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Come on.  Take a cue from me, I'm completely reinventing myself.  You know what, [_begins stretching his legs_] if I can learn a new language, write a bestseller, well then surely you can ask this woman out.  Now if you'll excuse me, I have a marathon to train for! _Frasier gets caught on the console and falls down behind the sofa. Niles and Martin rush to his aid._

speaker: Martin
text: Are you all right, Fras?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm fine.

speaker: Martin
text: What happened?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I think he tripped on one of these baskets.

speaker: Martin
text: Did you break anything?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Martin
text: Because, if you broke it, there's no point sending this one back either. _Martin takes another basket from the floor and heads to his chair whilst opening it.  Niles tends to Frasier.  FADE TO:  Scene Three - Frasier's Apartment. Frasier enters through the front door.  He is hobbling with his new cane.  Then Martin enters with his old cane.  They look at each other. Frasier has become his father._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear God.

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughs_] Look at you.  They gave you a sweet one.  All shiny and with no scuffs.  Still has that new cane smell.

speaker: Frasier
text: Play your cards right, I might let you take it for a spin around the lobby.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what they say?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just a little sprain.  It's gonna take a couple of weeks.

speaker: Frasier
text: I guess I'm going to have to rethink my life's plan a bit.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you're gonna be doing all this stuff?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course, Dad, why wouldn't I?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I don't know.  It just seems all so complicated.  The first one you tried was kind of a bust.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well you know, I've just got to scale things back a little bit.  Set my sights on more attainable goals.  For instance, here: "Visit South America."  That's in.  "Discover the lost treasure of the Incas."  That's out. [_deletes it_] "Take up rafting."  That's in.  "Retrace Lewis and Clarke's Route."  That's out.  And all this perpetual motion stuff, all this can go. [_deletes it_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh no, she's out for the whole evening.  You're gonna have to get it yourself.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right.

speaker: Martin
text: Let's see how that thing handles the corners.  Come on, open her up! _Frasier races to the door to find Niles and Mel dressed for an evening out._

speaker: Niles
text: Hello Frasier, I'd like you to meet Dr. Mel Karnofsky.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Mel_] Well, I can't tell you what a pleasure this is.

speaker: Niles
text: I believe you have some opera tickets for us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I do. [_fetches them_]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Mel, this is my father, Martin. [_Martin stands_]

speaker: Mel
text: Thank you.  We're very grateful for this.  Niles and I happen to be such huge fans of Puccini.

speaker: Martin
text: [_as Eddie enters_] Speaking of which, here is our own little "Pooch-ini"! _Mel greets Eddie as he licks her.  Mel seems to enjoy it and pets him. However when she stands up the hair brush comes up as Niles wipes her ear with a tissue.  Martin and Frasier give each other a look._

speaker: Frasier
text: So, where are you two having dinner?

speaker: Mel
text: Bel Canto, we have a table on the terrace.

speaker: Frasier
text: Terrace?  Well, I didn't know they had a terrace.

speaker: Mel
text: Really?  Well I guess you have to know the owner.  But, we better be going. I've pre-ordered our chocolate souffles and they'll be ready at seven-thirty precisely.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, off you go then.  Just remember, Niles, nothing puts on love handles faster than chocolate souffle.

speaker: Mel
text: Oh well, you know, no one takes them off faster than I do. [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Very funny, lovely meeting you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, she seems a bit much.

speaker: Martin
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, picking the restaurant, dining on the terrace, you have to know the owner.  Doesn't she remind you of someone?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, you!

speaker: Frasier
text: I was talking about Maris.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on, don't you think you're overreacting a little bit? I mean, Niles sure seems happy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you're right, Dad.  In fact, I've got a lot to accomplish this evening. [_sits on sofa_] Tonight, I'm going to start on my Russian language tapes.

speaker: Frasier
text: What is it, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: What?  Nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: What, don't you think I can do any of these things?

speaker: Martin
text: No, I think you can do anything you put your mind to, Frasier, you always have.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: I just wonder about all these projects.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as I said, I am streamlining.

speaker: Martin
text: You know, I think what you discovered this week was that something's missing from your life.  And before you start to fill it up with everything but the kitchen sink, I thought you ought to just ask yourself, "what do I really want?  What is really going to make me happy... now?"

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that's weird.  I suddenly feel like having a beer. _Martin gets up and exits to the kitchen, joyfully waving one of the meat logs from the Hickory Farms basket.  Frasier makes a decision. He stands up, punches a hole in one of the condolence baskets and takes a bottle of champagne from it. He heads out into the corridor, goes next door and knocks._

speaker: Frasier
text: Regan, it's me, Frasier!
